summary: Game of Thrones directors Alan Taylor and Jeremy Podeswa describe Jon Snow parentage revelation
body:
Game of Thrones directors Alan Taylor and Jeremy Podeswa describe Jon Snow parentage revelation

“It’s an epic revelation about the past, and that’s suggestive of the future,” Podeswa said, intriguingly. “For us, it was very important that there be a question about what could possibly happen after this moment. In the script, it described the fact that they were lovemaking, but it didn’t go into great detail in terms of what was going on between them in that moment.”

We built in a moment between  Kit [Harington] and Emilia [Clarke] where they stopped and looked into each other’s eyes. The intention from my point of view, and their point of view, too, is  that they’re driven by passion into this. They don’t even fully understand what it’s all about and what the consequences of it are.


https://winteriscoming.net/2018/08/14/game-of-thrones-directors-discuss-season-7s-biggest-moments/

“It’s an epic revelation about the past, and that’s suggestive of the future,” Podeswa said, intriguingly. “For us, it was very important that there be a question about what could possibly happen after this moment. In the script, it described the fact that they were lovemaking, but it didn’t go into great detail in terms of what was going on between them in that moment.”

We built in a moment between  Kit [Harington] and Emilia [Clarke] where they stopped and looked into each other’s eyes. title: Shadows 13 pre-teaser...??
body:
I was tagged by @iamthewatcheronthewall for the last sentence thing (which I think I’ve already done), but figured I’d use the opportunity to show that yes, I’m still writing. Haven’t abandoned all ye lovely folks yet. So here’s a little snippet of what’s going on at the moment. This is the mother of all drafts, meaning when I go back and re-read this stuff, it might change, but for now…have a taste (and thanks for being such patient, wonderful human beings) 

“Come on, boys,” she whispered as she quietly led them out of the house. She could keep them with her until Dany returned, and it wasn’t until she had secured them in the backseat, all but sped out of the estate, and was on the boulevard did she finally give in to the fear she’d managed to hold at bay during the exchange.

It took a lot to get her to cry for anything, but as the tears fell steadily, she prayed that Dany would be the one to put an end to all of this once and for all. No matter how hard a task it was going to be, she was the only one who could slam the door shut to this burgeoning dark chapter of their lives.

For as much as it pained her to admit this, the Jorah they both thought they knew, simply no longer existed.

Shadows

I was tagged by @iamthewatcheronthewall for the last sentence thing (which I think I’ve already done), but figured I’d use the opportunity to show that yes, I’m still writing. Haven’t abandoned all ye lovely folks yet. So here’s a little snippet of what’s going on at the moment. This is the mother of all drafts, meaning when I go back and re-read this stuff, it might change, but for now…have a taste (and thanks for being such patient, wonderful human beings) 

“Come on, boys,” she whispered as she quietly led them out of the house. She could keep them with her until Dany returned, and it wasn’t until she had secured them in the backseat, all but sped out of the estate, and was on the boulevard did she finally give in to the fear she’d managed to hold at bay during the exchange.

It took a lot to get her to cry for anything, but as the tears fell steadily, she prayed that Dany would be the one to put an end to all of this once and for all. No matter how hard a task it was going to be, she was the only one who could slam the door shut to this burgeoning dark chapter of their lives.

For as much as it pained her to admit this, the Jorah they both thought they knew, simply no longer existed.

summary: Okay so, we all know how during the open sequence each actor/actresses name has the sigil of their character's house by it....
body: Okay so, we all know how during the open sequence each actor/actresses name has the sigil of their character’s house by it. Kit’s has always been the direwolf sigil. I wonder if in s8 he’ll have the three-headed dragon sigil like Emilia? Or if it will have some direwolf dragon hybrid sigil? Personally I hope Jon will take up a unique sigil for himself that has both the direwolf and Dragon in s8, but that’s just me.

summary: One thing I know for sure is
body:
One thing I know for sure is

I’m actually kind of excited to see Jon’s reaction when he finds out he’s a Targaryen, and Dany’s his aunt.. Like I’m living to see what kind of reaction my boy Jon Snow has.

summary: hi! i really appreciate your blog! why didn’t ned tell cat the truth about jon’s parentage? and jon too for that matter? (sorry...
question: hi! i really appreciate your blog! why didn’t ned tell cat the truth about jon’s parentage? and jon too for that matter? (sorry if you’ve answered this before)
answer:
It’s all down to the promise Ned made Lyanna before she died. We don’t know what exactly the words of the promise were, but almost certainly it involved keeping her son safe, and making sure Robert never found out about his parentage. (As he wanted all Targaryens dead, and considered Rhaegar’s murdered children “only dragonspawn”.) It very probably included Ned promising to raise the boy as his own, as well. And it can’t have included “to one day tell him he’s the true heir”, or Ned would never have allowed Jon to join the Night’s Watch.

Troubled sleep was no stranger to him. He had lived his lies for fourteen years, yet they still haunted him at night. –AGOT, Eddard II

He thought of the promises he’d made Lyanna as she lay dying, and the price he’d paid to keep them. –AGOT, Eddard IX

The lies we tell for love, he thought. –AGOT, Eddard XIII

Why Catelyn was not included in the secret–

  • because it was deeply dangerous. If Robert had found out, his anger against the ex-friend who lied to him and betrayed his trust would have been dreadful and unyielding… how could Ned share this fear with an innocent woman? What if she felt she couldn’t bear the danger for herself or for her children?
  • because it was deeply dishonorable. How could he make his beloved wife live a life of lies, of lies to the king, of lies to her children? Ned wanted the dishonor for himself alone, which is why (among other, timeline reasons) he didn’t say Jon was Brandon’s bastard, why he refused to allow gossipers in Winterfell say Ashara was Jon’s mother.
  • because it wouldn’t have helped Cat’s relationship with Jon if she had to keep the secret from him, as she would have still had to treat him like a noble wife treats her husband’s bastard, and the strain of the lies and false faces would have been too much to deal with.
  • because it may have been that the promise to Lyanna included, “tell no one else, promise me, Ned.”

Some secrets are safer kept hidden. Some secrets are too dangerous to share, even with those you love and trust. –AGOT, Eddard VIII

Ned thought, If it came to that, the life of some child I did not know, against Robb and Sansa and Arya and Bran and Rickon, what would I do? Even more so, what would Catelyn do, if it were Jon’s life, against the children of her body?  He did not know. He prayed he never would. –AGOT, Eddard XII

“…let them grow up close as brothers, with only love between them,” he prayed, “and let my lady wife find it in her heart to forgive…” –ADWD, Bran III

Why Jon was not included in the secret–

  • because he was a child. (Still only 14 when he left for the Wall.) How could Ned entrust a child with a secret of this magnitude and danger? How could he make a child lie to his siblings, lie to everyone he met?
  • because, again, it may have been that the promise to Lyanna included, “never tell him, Ned, never let him know the truth, promise me.”

Nevertheless, one of Ned’s regrets, when he’s in the black cells arrested for treason, is that he never told Jon about his mother.

The thought of Jon filled Ned with a sense of shame, and a sorrow too deep for words. If only he could see the boy again, sit and talk with him… –AGOT, Eddard XV

“…let them grow up close as brothers, with only love between them,” he prayed, “and let my lady wife find it in her heart to forgive…” –ADWD, Bran III

Why Jon was not included in the secret–

  • because he was a child. (Still only 14 when he left for the Wall.) How could Ned entrust a child with a secret of this magnitude and danger? How could he make a child lie to his siblings, lie to everyone he met?
  • because, again, it may have been that the promise to Lyanna included, “never tell him, Ned, never let him know the truth, promise me.”

Nevertheless, one of Ned’s regrets, when he’s in the black cells arrested for treason, is that he never told Jon about his mother.

The thought of Jon filled Ned with a sense of shame, and a sorrow too deep for words. If only he could see the boy again, sit and talk with him… –AGOT, Eddard XV
trail.content:
It’s all down to the promise Ned made Lyanna before she died. We don’t know what exactly the words of the promise were, but almost certainly it involved keeping her son safe, and making sure Robert never found out about his parentage. (As he wanted all Targaryens dead, and considered Rhaegar’s murdered children “only dragonspawn”.) It very probably included Ned promising to raise the boy as his own, as well. And it can’t have included “to one day tell him he’s the true heir”, or Ned would never have allowed Jon to join the Night’s Watch.

Troubled sleep was no stranger to him. He had lived his lies for fourteen years, yet they still haunted him at night. –AGOT, Eddard II

He thought of the promises he’d made Lyanna as she lay dying, and the price he’d paid to keep them. –AGOT, Eddard IX

The lies we tell for love, he thought. –AGOT, Eddard XIII

Why Catelyn was not included in the secret–

  • because it was deeply dangerous. If Robert had found out, his anger against the ex-friend who lied to him and betrayed his trust would have been dreadful and unyielding… how could Ned share this fear with an innocent woman? What if she felt she couldn’t bear the danger for herself or for her children?
  • because it was deeply dishonorable. How could he make his beloved wife live a life of lies, of lies to the king, of lies to her children? Ned wanted the dishonor for himself alone, which is why (among other, timeline reasons) he didn’t say Jon was Brandon’s bastard, why he refused to allow gossipers in Winterfell say Ashara was Jon’s mother.
  • because it wouldn’t have helped Cat’s relationship with Jon if she had to keep the secret from him, as she would have still had to treat him like a noble wife treats her husband’s bastard, and the strain of the lies and false faces would have been too much to deal with.
  • because it may have been that the promise to Lyanna included, “tell no one else, promise me, Ned.”

Some secrets are safer kept hidden. Some secrets are too dangerous to share, even with those you love and trust. –AGOT, Eddard VIII

Ned thought, If it came to that, the life of some child I did not know, against Robb and Sansa and Arya and Bran and Rickon, what would I do? Even more so, what would Catelyn do, if it were Jon’s life, against the children of her body?  He did not know. He prayed he never would. –AGOT, Eddard XII

“…let them grow up close as brothers, with only love between them,” he prayed, “and let my lady wife find it in her heart to forgive…” –ADWD, Bran III

Why Jon was not included in the secret–

  • because he was a child. (Still only 14 when he left for the Wall.) How could Ned entrust a child with a secret of this magnitude and danger? How could he make a child lie to his siblings, lie to everyone he met?
  • because, again, it may have been that the promise to Lyanna included, “never tell him, Ned, never let him know the truth, promise me.”

Nevertheless, one of Ned’s regrets, when he’s in the black cells arrested for treason, is that he never told Jon about his mother.

The thought of Jon filled Ned with a sense of shame, and a sorrow too deep for words. If only he could see the boy again, sit and talk with him… –AGOT, Eddard XV

tags: he has so many great quotes
summary: JON SNOW WEEK | Day Two Favorite Quote › “We look up at the same stars, and see such different things.”  So many stars, he...
caption:
JON SNOW WEEK | Day Two
Favorite Quote › “We look up at the same stars, and see such different things.”

So many stars, he thought as he trudged up the slope through pines and firs and ash. Maester Luwin had taught him his stars as a boy in Winterfell; he had learned the names of the twelve houses of heaven and the rulers of each; he could find the seven wanderers sacred to the Faith; he was old friends with the Ice Dragon, the Shadowcat, the Moonmaid, and the Sword of the Morning. | ASOS · Jon III
